channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Accuses Dissidents and Ukraine of Killing Pro-War Blogger
item.description: The authorities detained a woman they said had delivered the bomb, hidden in a statuette, that killed the blogger, and called it the work of antigovernment activists and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A memorial for the Russian blogger Vladlen Tatarsky, who was killed in a bomb blast, in St. Petersburg on Monday.

item.title: Strange Days at the U.N. as Russia Takes the Helm of the Security Council
item.description: The monthlong presidency of an organization dedicated to preserving world peace is now in the hands of a nation waging the biggest land war in Europe in decades.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The United Nations headquarters in New York in September.

item.title: Pro-War Bloggers Like One Killed in Bombing Are an Influential Group
item.description: The blogger killed in a bombing in St. Petersburg was one of the influential ultranationalists pushing for harsher pursuit of Russia’s war against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Police officers on Monday outside a cafe in St. Petersburg, Russia, where the blogger Vladlen Tatarsky was killed in a bomb explosion.

item.title: Electric Rental Scooters to be Banned in Paris After Referendum
item.description: A referendum emphasized how many residents had come to regard the scooters as dangerous nuisances with little environmental benefit. Other cities were closely watching the vote.
item.dc:creator: Tom Nouvian
item.media:description: Relatively few people turned out for the referendum about the scooters — only about 100,000 Parisians voted, less than 7.5 percent of those eligible — but nearly 89 percent backed the ban.

item.title: The Challenges of Ukraine’s Coming Counteroffensive
item.description: With powerful Western weapons, newly formed assault units and even a reconstituted Azov battalion, Ukraine is poised for a critical spring counteroffensive. But overcoming casualties and keeping war-weary troops motivated will be stern tests.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Ex-Leader of Kosovo Pleads Not Guilty to War Crimes Charges
item.description: Hashim Thaci, the former president and prime minister, went on trial in The Hague on charges related to the country’s bloody fight for independence.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Hashim Thaci, then the president of Kosovo, greeting supporters on his return to the country after being interviewed in The Hague about alleged war crimes in July 2020.

item.title: North Korean Workers Toil in Russia and China, Despite Sanctions
item.description: Despite sanctions and the pandemic, laborers from the country remain abroad, earning desperately needed cash for the regime, according to a new report.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: North Korean workers in 2019 waiting for their flight at an airport in Vladivostok, Russia. Under a United Nations Security Council resolution, countries were required to expel all North Korean workers by the end of 2019.

item.title: The Yearslong Fight To Get Paul Rusesabagina Out of Rwanda
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina, depicted in the 2004 film about genocide in his country, was reunited with his family last week. It took years of pressure to get him out of Rwanda, where he was convicted on terrorism charges.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Michael D. Shear and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Paul Rusesabagina in a prisoner uniform outside the court in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, in 2020.

item.title: Malka Leifer Found Guilty in Student Sexual Abuse Case in Australia
item.description: Malka Leifer, who had led an ultra-Orthodox Jewish girls’ school in Melbourne, was found guilty of sexually abusing students more than 15 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Malka Leifer being brought to a courtroom in Jerusalem in 2018.

item.title: ‘What Happened to My Brother?’: A Desperate Search in Mexico
item.description: After a deadly fire in a migrant detention center in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, some victims’ families and friends are still looking for answers about their loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Salazar and Noah Throop

item.title: Blinken Demands Release of Evan Gershkovich in Call With Lavrov
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke with his Russian counterpart after the American basketball star Brittney Griner, who was detained for almost 10 months by Russia, urged the U.S. government to use “every tool possible” to secure Evan Gershkovich’s release.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, was escorted by officers from a court in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Revival Is Ever-Present Possibility for World Leaders
item.description: The indictment last week of Donald J. Trump has not changed the calculations of many world leaders who view his political resilience as inevitable.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump last month in Waco, Texas.

item.title: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen Balances China and U.S.
item.description: Known for her quiet pragmatism, Tsai Ing-wen has ushered in a new era of American cooperation as worries about Chinese aggression rise.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Amy Chang Chien, Chris Horton and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan’s president, at National Day celebrations in October 2021.

item.title: Andrew Tate Is Released From Jail and Placed Under House Arrest
item.description: Mr. Tate, the social media influencer, and his brother Tristan had been in custody since December, when they were arrested on allegations of human trafficking, rape and forming an organized criminal group.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Andrew Tate, center, and his brother Tristan were released from a detention facility in Bucharest, Romania, on Friday.

item.title: Train Derails in the Netherlands, Killing at Least One
item.description: The passenger train, which was on its way to The Hague, struck a crane early Tuesday morning, officials said. Dozens were hurt.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and John Yoon
item.media:description: The site of a derailed train in Voorschoten, the Netherlands, on Tuesday.

item.title: As Temperatures Rise, Melbourne’s Bats Get Their Own Sprinkler System
item.description: On the hottest days, a refreshing mist will cool down flying foxes, which have suffered mass death in Australian heat waves.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Christina Simons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flying fox bats at a release facility in the Yarra Bend Park in Melbourne, Australia.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Fallout from a bombing in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A memorial for the Russian blogger Vladlen Tatarsky, who was killed in a bomb blast, in St. Petersburg on Monday.

item.title: Nigel Lawson, Economic Force Under Thatcher, Dies at 91
item.description: As chancellor of the Exchequer, he helped lift Britain with tax cuts and other Conservative measures — the “Lawson Boom” — but harder times followed, and he resigned in bitterness.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:description: As chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson was closely associated with Mrs. Thatcher’s hallmark drive for deregulation and the privatization of huge state enterprises and utilities.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Ukraine Prepares a Counteroffensive
item.description: Also, Trump returns to New York to surrender and North Koreans remain in “state-sponsored slavery” abroad.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monitoring Russian troop movements from a fortified position near the front line in eastern Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich, WSJ Reporter Detained in Russia, Appeals His Arrest
item.description: Mr. Gershkovich was detained last Thursday while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinberg, Russia. His newspaper, The Wall Street Journal, and U.S. officials reject the charges of espionage against him as bogus.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, 31, was detained by Russian authorities and accused of espionage while on a reporting trip in the city of Yekaterinburg last week. He is now being held in Moscow.

item.title: Woman Arrested In Russian Blogger’s Death Attended Opposition Rallies
item.description: Russian investigators arrested Daria Trepova, a 26-year-old native of St. Petersburg, on Monday in connection with the killing of the blogger known as Vladlen Tatarsky
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Alina Lobzina and Oleg Matsnev
item.media:description: A police officer stands guard on Monday at the scene of an explosion in which Vladlen Tatarsky was killed in St. Petersburg, Russia.

item.title: Migrants Search for Bodies of Loved Ones After Mexico Fire
item.description: After a deadly fire in a migrant detention center in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, some victims’ families and friends are still looking for answers about their loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Salazar and Noah Throop

item.title: New Marburg Outbreaks in Africa Raise Alarm About the Deadly Virus’s Spread
item.description: The spread of the Ebola-like virus has claimed lives but could be a crucial chance to test a vaccine — if supplies and researchers are mobilized in time.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: World Health Organization officials visited the home of a possible victim of the Marburg virus during an outbreak in Angola in 2005. There are currently two outbreaks on both the west and east coasts of Africa.

item.title: Wagner Claims ‘Legal’ Control of Bakhmut, While Ukraine Says It Is Still Fighting
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Wagner group founder, said Russian forces had raised their country’s flag in the center of Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Bakhmut, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: The Year’s Biggest Election
item.description: The battle for a state Supreme Court seat in Wisconsin.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Wisconsin state capitol.

item.title: Hoping to Travel Abroad? Don’t Put Off Your Passport Application.
item.description: Processing times for new and renewed passports have increased again. The updated timeline, 10 to 13 weeks, leaves some would-be travelers feeling desperate.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A passport being stamped at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York.

item.title: Speculation flares after an influential Russian military blogger is killed by a bomb in St. Petersburg.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: The Russian blogger known as Vladlen Tatarsky was killed on Sunday when a bomb exploded at a talk he was giving at a cafe in St. Petersburg, Russia.

item.title: Russia’s assault in eastern Ukraine appears stalled.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier firing a rocket-propelled grenade toward Russian forces from a trench in an area of Marinka, in eastern Ukraine, in February.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s expected surrender at a Manhattan courthouse.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Barricades lined the streets for blocks around Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue.

item.title: Milo Djukanovic Is Defeated in Montenegro’s Presidential Election
item.description: The incumbent, Milo Djukanovic, conceded to Jakov Milatovic, who had campaigned on pledges to root out corruption and organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Supporters of Jakov Milatovic celebrated in Podgorica, the capital of Montenegro, on Sunday after the presidential election.

item.title: Sanna Marin’s Party Loses in Finland Election
item.description: Prime Minister Sanna Marin’s party was outpolled by a rival that stressed economic concerns. Petteri Orpo of the National Coalition Party may now come to power, but coalition talks will be daunting.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: Supporters of Petteri Orpo, the National Coalition Party leader, in Helsinki, Finland, on Sunday.

item.title: How the U.S. Came to Use NSO Spyware It Was Trying to Kill
item.description: The Biden administration has been trying to choke off use of hacking tools made by the Israeli firm NSO. It turns out that not every part of the government has gotten the message.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Legal Tactics
item.description: Also, China’s lessons from the war in Ukraine and Volodymyr Zelensky denounces Russia’s U.N. role.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump in Waco, Texas, last month.

item.title: Israel Moves Forward With Far-Right Plan for National Guard
item.description: Itamar Ben-Gvir, one of the most extreme voices in the Israeli government, had long sought to create a national guard. Ministers agreed on Sunday to set up a committee to discuss next steps.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Itamar Ben-Gvir, a cabinet minister who was once a marginal activist, in Jerusalem last week.

item.title: Vladlen Tatarsky, Russian Military Blogger, Is Killed in St. Petersburg Bombing
item.description: Vladlen Tatarsky represented a radical wing of pro-invasion bloggers and activists who backed Moscow’s war but also criticized what they saw as the flaws in the Russian Army.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Police officers on Monday outside a cafe in St. Petersburg, Russia, where the blogger Vladlen Tatarsky was killed in a bomb explosion.

item.title: Pope Francis, Back From the Hospital, Thanks Palm Sunday Crowds
item.description: Francis arrived in St. Peter’s Square in an open-topped jeep on Palm Sunday, the beginning of a week of major ceremonies before Easter.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis speaking to tens of thousands of faithful gathered for Palm Sunday Mass in St. Peter’s Square.

item.title: Maggie Haberman on Donald Trump
item.description: We talk with a Trump reporter to prepare you for the week when he will likely be arrested.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Former President Donald Trump gesturing to supporters.

item.title: Fight Over Corruption and Congo’s Mining Riches Takes a Turn in Washington
item.description: Dan Gertler, an Israeli billionaire, is pressing President Biden to remove sanctions that were imposed on him for bribe-fueled transactions in the impoverished African country.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: Dan Gertler, an Israeli diamond dealer, has found a surprising ally in his quest to have his name removed from a U.S. sanctions list: the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: Maria Lvova-Belova, the Children’s Rights Advocate Accused of Russian War Crimes
item.description: Maria Lvova-Belova says she is running a humanitarian evacuation of abandoned Ukrainian children. The International Criminal Court accuses her of abducting them wholesale.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Mikhail Metzel/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Maria Lvova-Belova, Russia’s commissioner for children’s rights, meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin outside Moscow in February in a photograph released by the Russian state media.

item.title: Residents of Avdiivka in Ukraine Refuse to Leave Battered City
item.description: Huddled in basements just over a mile away from the front lines of Avdiivka, over 1,800 residents are refusing to be rescued from one of the most active battlegrounds in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

item.title: Refusing to Evacuate, Ukrainian Residents Go Underground
item.description: Huddled in basements just over a mile away from the front lines of Avdiivka, over 1,800 residents are refusing to be rescued from one of the most active battlegrounds in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: Forest Fire Breaks Out on a Mountain in Central Seoul
item.description: Dozens of nearby homes were evacuated as firefighters hurried to contain the blaze on one of Seoul’s most popular hiking sites.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Inwangsan, a mountain in central Seoul, where a forest fire broke out on Sunday, is a popular destination.

item.title: Russian Shelling Kills 6 as Assault Stalls in Ukraine’s East
item.description: The attack came after President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that permitting Moscow its monthlong presidency of the Security Council showed “the complete bankruptcy of such institutions.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Maria Varenikova and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers collecting the body of one of six victims from shelling that hit the courtyard of residential buildings in Kostyantynivka, in eastern Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: No More Blank Checks: Saudi Arabia Clamps Down on Regional Aid
item.description: The kingdom used to send money to poorer countries like Egypt with few strings attached. But it is increasingly leveraging its economic power for influence in the Middle East and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Bandar Al-Jaloud/Saudi Royal Palace, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Saudi Royal Palace showing Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, left, and President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi of Egypt in June at the presidential palace in Cairo.

item.title: Green Savior or Deadly Menace? Paris Votes on E-Scooter Ban
item.description: For five years, the French capital has permitted the renting of electric scooters, which have proven both popular and perilous. On Sunday, voters will decide whether to end the experiment.
item.dc:creator: Tom Nouvian
item.media:description: Riding an electric scooter in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Bring the Kids Along
item.description: We take our children on vacation to expose them to history, novelty and beauty.
item.dc:creator: Amy Virshup

item.title: Far-Left Canadians Susceptible to Russian Influence Too
item.description: Researchers found that on Twitter, members of Canada’s far left joined those on the far right in embracing pro-Russian messages created by a two-year Russian influence campaign.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at the commemoration ceremony for Armistice Day, 100 years after the end of World War I, in Paris in 2018.

item.title: Ukraine Charges a Leading Ukrainian Vicar, as Russia Pounds Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The charge against the religious leader, Pavlo Lebid, came as Russian forces hit the town of Avdiivka, among 70 other targets, along the front line.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Metropolitan Pavlo Lebid at the end of the morning service at the Pechersk Lavra on Thursday. Ukraine’s security service charged Mr. Lebid on Saturday with being in league with Russia and supporting Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Venice Is Saved! Woe Is Venice.
item.description: Produced by Mona Boshnaq
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Emma Bubola and Laetitia Vancon

item.title: Thailand’s Unemployed Elephants Are Back Home, Huge and Hungry
item.description: When the tourists who rode them disappeared from resort destinations, Thailand’s captive elephants, and their owners, went back to their birth villages, where finding enough food has been a struggle.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elephants are a common sight on the streets of Baan Ta Klang village, in Thailand. Here, a mahout rides his elephant past a sculpture of a mythical, multiheaded elephant in February.

item.title: Why Is Finland the Happiest Country on Earth? The Answer Is Complicated.
item.description: The Nordic nation has been ranked the happiest country on earth for six consecutive years. But when you talk to individual Finns, the reality is a bit more complicated.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Colston and Jake Michaels
item.media:credit: Jake Michaels for The New York Times
item.media:description: Henna and Niklas Hukari, siblings who play badminton in the rural community of Toholampi, are among more than a dozen Finns we spoke with about how optimism manifests in their lives.

item.title: China Draws Lessons From Russia’s Missteps in Ukraine
item.description: With an eye on a possible conflict over Taiwan, analysts have scrutinized the war for insights ranging from the importance of supply lines to the power of nuclear threats.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: New recruits of the People’s Liberation Army at a send-off ceremony in eastern China. Experts studying Russia’s war have said that Moscow’s manpower shortfall shows that China needed to keep its ground forces strong.

item.title: Security Force or Anti-Arab Militia? Israelis Feud Over Far-Right Plan
item.description: The far-right security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, wants to create a national guard that he would control, saying it is needed to guarantee Israel’s security.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Itamar Ben-Gvir in Jerusalem in October.

item.title: Pope Francis Quips He’s ‘Still Alive’ After Hospital Stay
item.description: The 86-year-old pontiff spent three days undergoing treatment for bronchitis at a hospital in Rome.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis leaving the hospital in Rome on Saturday. The Vatican said he would take part in all of the Holy Week celebrations.

item.title: Inside Saudi Arabia’s Global Push for Nuclear Power
item.description: Despite qualms in Washington, Saudi officials have pressed the United States to help them develop nuclear power. But they are also exploring other options, including China.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Vivian Nereim and Kate Kelly
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Looking over Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Saudi officials are exploring options to work with countries other than the United States to develop a nuclear energy program.

item.title: Gift of a Stethoscope to a Refugee Child Inspired a Career of Caring
item.description: Waheed Arian fled the war in Afghanistan when he was a teenager. Now an emergency room doctor in Britain, he has made it his mission to bring hope and healing to others.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waheed Arian, a doctor in Chester, England, was once an asylum seeker from Afghanistan.

item.title: Israeli Police Fatally Shoot Arab Outside Jerusalem Holy Site
item.description: The man was shot dead early Saturday at the edge of the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount. The circumstances of the killing were disputed and risked raising tensions during Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Crowds of worshipers outside the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, on Friday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Step Up Recruitment, Bracing for Fights Ahead
item.description: After a winter of intense battles and heavy losses in Ukraine’s east, both Russia and Ukraine are taking steps to replenish their depleted forces.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers monitor movements of Russian troops from their fortified position on the front line in Toretsk, eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.
